description: Borrowed from Latin fragor (“a breaking to pieces”), from frangō (“to break”).

entries.meaning: A loud and sudden sound; the report of anything bursting; a crash.
examples: The direful fragor, when some southern blast / Tears from the Alps a ridge of knotty oaks […]

description: From the above, by confusion with the root of fragrant.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, proscribed) A strong or sweet scent; fragrance.
